Ihre Nieren sind lebenswichtige Organe, die Ihr Blut filtern und reinigen und den Salz- und Wassergehalt in Ihrem Kö
Wenn Sie gesund sind, geht dieses stä
column2: ndige Filtern und Reinigen unbemerkt vonstatten, aber es kann bei Ihnen aus vielen Gr&uuml
column4: bergehenden oder dauerhaften Nierenversagen kommen. Es haben nie zwei Patienten exakt das gleiche Krankheitsbild, einige haben m&ouml
column5: glicherweise auch noch weitere Erkrankungen neben Nierenproblemen.

column2: digung der Nieren, die sich mit der Zeit verschlimmern und schlie&szlig
column4: hren kann. Unsere Aufgabe bei Diaverum besteht darin, Ihnen dabei zu helfen, trotz Ihrer Diagnose so normal wie m&ouml
column5: glich zu leben. Wir widmen einen Gro&szlig
column6: teil unserer Arbeit auch der Aufgabe, den Menschen zu helfen, die Nierenfunktion zu verstehen und nachzuvollziehen, wie man Nierenerkrankungen am besten vorbeugen oder sie behandeln und damit umgehen kann, falls sie dennoch auftreten.

column1: Wie auch immer wir Ihnen helfen, wir vergessen nie, dass Sie als Individuum im Mittelpunkt unserer Arbeit stehen. Wir bieten Ihnen eine umfassende medizinische Behandlung aus einer Hand, die nicht nur die beste individuelle Behandlung Ihrer Nierenprobleme bietet, sondern auch die Behandlung weiterer Erkrankungen, unter denen Sie mö
column2: glicherweise leiden. Auch bei einer Nierentransplantation k&ouml
column3: nnen wir Sie durch Vorbereitung und Nachsorge unterst&uuml
column4: tzen. Auf diese Weise wollen wir Ihnen zu einem m&ouml
column5: glichst normalen Leben verhelfen und dabei das Fortschreiten Ihrer Nierenerkrankung m&ouml

column2: chte so beginnen, denn ich bin ein sehr gl&uuml

column1: Ich schreibe Ihnen von einem wunderbaren und ruhigen Ort. Ich bin am Toten Meer, in Israel, mit Blick auf die Berge in Jordanien. Hier ist alles still und friedlich, und unter dem Eindruck dieses Gefü
column7: hlen, wie ein Nierenpatient ein erf&uuml

column1: Ich habe sehr klare Erinnerungen an den Tag, an dem ich die erste Dialyse bekam. Es war der 19. April 2017. Ich ging in den Operationssaal, wo mir ein Katheter gelegt wurde, und gleich danach wurde mit der Dialyse begonnen. Es war eine dreistü
column2: ndige Behandlung. Ich habe damals nicht viel dar&uuml
column3: ber gesprochen, weil ich es nicht wahrhaben wollte. Es war nicht leicht, das zu akzeptieren, und ich erinnere mich, Freunde und Familie angerufen zu haben, um herauszufinden, ob jemand eine Blutgruppe hat, die mit meiner kompatibel war. Es fand sich aber kein geeigneter Spender.

column2: ter wurde mein Sohn Guilherme geboren. Die gr&ouml
column4: te Liebe meines Lebens war da, in meinen Armen, mit einem Gewicht von etwas mehr als 3000&nbsp
column5: g. Ich erinnere mich, dass ich dachte: Hiermit entscheide ich mich, f&uuml

column1: Das waren die zehn Tage, die es dauerte, bis ich verstanden hatte, was ich verstehen musste: Alles. Wie alles funktioniert. Und ich begann Interesse an der Krankheit und der Dialyse als solcher zu entwickeln. Das war der Moment, in dem ich beschloss, dass die Krankheit mich nicht unterkriegen wü
column4: chte ich Ihnen von den vier Schritten erz&auml

Maria - 33 Jahre in der Dialyse Kleve
Shirley - eine inspirierende Krankenschwester bei Diaverum

Ich bin Maria Venhoff und hab vor langer Zeit nach meine Ausbildung auf der Inneren Abteilung im St. Josef Krankenhaus in Moers gearbeitet.
Nach der Geburt meines 2. Kindes habe ich meine Arbeitstage auf jedes zweite Wochenende und jeden zweiten Feiertag beschrä
column2: nkt. Zu dieser Zeit suchte Dr. Paul eine Krankenschwester f&uuml
column3: r seine amublante Dialyseeinrichtung in Abendschicht in Kleve. Ich hab mich vorgestellt und wurde sofort eingestellt. Am Anfang war es eine stressige Zeit, da ich keinerlei Erfahrung in der Dialyse mitbrachte. Ich habe manche Nacht von piependen Maschinen getr&auml
column5: em Engagement hab ich mich der neuen Aufgabe gewidmet und nie den Spa&szlig
column6: daran verloren. Das zeigt auch meine lange Zugeh&ouml
column7: rigkeit in der Dialyse Kleve, die nun bereits 33 Jahre betr&auml
column8:
gt. Und auch als das Zentrum 2010 zu Diaverum wurde, ist die Freude geblieben.
Mein Arbeitsbereich umfasst sä
column9: mtliche Aufgaben wie Patientenbetreuung, Organisation, Bestellung, Rechnungspr&uuml
column13: e Eigenverantwortung, die technischen Anforderungen und sogar die Dokumentationsaufgaben. Seit einigen Jahren hab ich die Pflegedienstleitung des Zentrums &uuml
column14: bernommen, die eine Menge Personalverantwortung mit sich bringt. Und gerade die Arbeit in einem gutem Team, welches mich jederzeit nach Kr&auml
column17: ber all die Jahre motiviert und mich dazu bewegt Tag f&uuml
column18: r Tag in die Arbeit zu gehen!

Am 4. und 5. Mai 2023 fand in Erfurt zum 31. Mal die Dialysefachtagung fü
column4: rzte statt. Diaverum Deutschland beteiligte sich zum ersten Mal sowohl mit einem Stand in der Industrieausstellung als auch mit einem Vortrag.

column1: Diaverum konnte als einer der wenigen Servicedienstleister in der Industrieausstellung die Aufmerksamkeit der pflegerischen Besucher:innen auf den Stand lenken. Dabei wurden unter anderem Anfragen fü
column3: glichkeiten und das Konzept zur Patientenschulung interessiert aufgenommen.
am Donnerstag fand in der Form eines Vortrags zum Thema &bdquo
column4: Wie digitales Monitoring der Wasseraufbereitung mehr Zeit f&uuml
column6: in Kooperation mit der GreenTec Dialysis GmbH statt. Jennifer Hempel, Pflegedienstleitung des
column7: MVZ Diaverum Erkelenz, lieferte dabei Einblicke in die Arbeit mit dem neuen digitalen &Uuml

column4: Wir setzen seit einigen Wochen auf die digitale &Uuml
column5: berwachung der Wasseraufbereitung und merken jetzt schon, dass wir mehr Zeit f&uuml
column6: r die Patienten haben. Mit dem Vortrag in Erfurt konnten wir gute Impulse geben. Wir haben uns &uuml
column7: ber den zahlreichen Zuspruch sehr gefreut.&ldquo

column1: Auch der Abend, welchem Diaverum auf Einladung von GreenTec gefolgt ist, war sehr angenehm. In lockerer Atmosphä
column2: re konnten wir viele neue Kontakte kn&uuml

column4: In diesem Jahr waren wir zum ersten Mal als Aussteller und mit einem Vortrag bei der Fachtagung dabei. Wir konnten sowohl durch unseren Stand als auch im Nachgang des Vortrags wertvolle Kontakte kn&uuml

column3: ler Luca und Nico haben am 27. April 2023 den Boys' Day genutzt, um einen Blick in den Arbeitsalltag des MVZ Stralsund zu werfen.

column2: hrte die Pflegedienstleitung Grit Kolbe, zusammen mit Cassandra H&auml
column3: uer, Auszubildende im 3. Lehrjahr, und Wolfgang Rudolf, Fachpfleger f&uuml
column4: r Nephrologie. Die Jugendlichen lernten das Team kennen, den Standort im Jungfernstieg und die verschiedenen Ausbildungsm&ouml
column5: glichkeiten, die Diaverum in Stralsund anbietet.

column3: lern anschaulich das Grundprinzip der Dialyse und der Wasserversorgung. Er hatte einige praktische Beispiele mitgebracht und lockerte das Gespr&auml

column2: r einen Bericht aus Patientensicht konnte eine Peritonealdialyse-Patientin gewonnen werden. Sie berichtete &uuml
column4: hrige Erfahrung mit der Bauchfelldialyse und &uuml
column5: ber ihre Versorgung und Betreuung bei Diaverum.

column2: lich erfuhren die Jugendlichen von Cassandra H&auml
column3: uer, wie sie zur MFA-Ausbildung gekommen ist

column1: Insgesamt war es ein gelungener Tag und wir hoffe, dass wir den beiden Schü
column2: lern einen kleinen aber doch umfassenden Einblick in den Alltag in einem Dialysezentrum geben konnten. In jeden Fall freuen wir uns jetzt schon auf den n&auml

Your kidneys are vital for your survival
<div class=""row""><div class=""block editorialblock col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 display-mode-narrow "">        <div class=""rich-text"">
Your kidneys are vital for your survival. Their main tasks are to filter waste substances out of your blood and balance the levels of salts and water in your body.

At Diaverum, our mission is to enhance the lives of renal patients, enabling them to live fulfilling lives. An essential part of this is to raise awareness of the importance of kidneys, how to protect them, and to know how they work - knowledge that forms a major part of our efforts to educate patients on health and the value of prevention.
Several kidney diseases can damage our kidneys temporarily or permanently, which may lead to the development of various co-morbidities. Each patient has unique disease pattern.

At Diaverum, we take this into account and treat each of our patients as individuals, with a patient-centric approach. Moreover, we provide renal patients with comprehensive medical care from a single source, using a Care Delivery Model underpinned by a continuously evolving digital infrastructure.
That means we do not only offer the best individual treatment for our patients, but that we also treat the co-morbidities and offer transplant preparation and aftercare.
Our treatment aims to give our patients the chance to live as normal life as possible and help them with slowing the progression of Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD).
Our focus is haemodialysis, but our portfolio of treatments ranges from preventive care to transplantation services.
A holistic treatment of our patients is the center of everything we do.
Enabling patients to live a fulfilling life

Looking for a Diaverum Clinic? Use Clinic Finder
Filipe: a dialysis patient and world traveler

column2: t life a wonderful thing? I&rsquo
column3: d like to start in this way, because I feel like I&rsquo

column2: m writing to you from a wonderful and calm place. I&rsquo
column3: m at the Dead Sea, in Israel, with a view of the mountains in Jordan. Everything is silent and peaceful here and it is under the spell of this feeling that I&rsquo
column4: d like to tell you more about my adventure. I want to tell you about how a renal patient can have a fulfilling life.

column1: I have very clear memories of the day when I started dialysis. It was April 19 2017. I went to the surgery room to get a catheter placed and, right after that, I was started on dialysis. It was a three-hour treatment. I didn&rsquo
column2: t talk a lot about it at the time, because I was in denial. It wasn&rsquo
column3: t easy to accept and I remember calling friends and family to see if anyone had a blood type compatible with mine. No suitable donor materialised.

column1: Ten days later, my son Guilherme was born. The greatest love of my life was there, in my arms, weighing in at a little more than 3 kg. I remember thinking: Now, I choose to live for you.

Those were the ten days that I needed to understand what I needed to understand: Everything. How everything worked. And I started getting interested in the disease and the dialysis process itself. That was the moment at which I decided that the disease wouldn&rsquo
column2: t be stronger than me, and that&rsquo
column3: s why I want to share with you the four steps I have taken to get where I am today: happier than ever, and living my lifelong dream.

column1: My medical report claimed that I had an incapacity of 71.4%. My body was so tired after treatments that I&rsquo
column2: d spend the next day sleeping or resting. I found myself looking in the mirror and feeling sorry for myself. I was only 28 years old and expecting a future of never working again, spending all my time hooked up to a machine.

column1: Our first thought is often: How will others see me now? These are the words that our brains process and that make us complain about everything with everyone around us. These are the words that, in an instant, make us believe that nobody will ever love us. In that moment, we lose a grip on the true value we have. This is where I feel the first battle takes place: eliminating the attitudes that aren&rsquo
column2: t good for us. Starting to understand the disease and the treatment was very important for me, in order to mentally digest the fact that this process, the treatment, is what allowed me to stay alive.

column1: We can only be truly happy when we understand that dialysis isn&rsquo
column2: t something bad. On the contrary, we are fortunate that these treatments exist, which allow us to continue our lives with those we love and keep on doing the things we enjoy. Once we have realised that, we can take the next step. Now, I am more thankful for all the good things in my life and I have stopped wasting my time complaining and whining.

column1: What am I good at? What do I really love doing? I&rsquo
column2: d opened a tourism company in February 2017, and, for the first time in my life, became self-employed. It was never anything I&rsquo
column3: d planned, but just something that happened. I&rsquo
column4: d invested a lot of money in order to pursue something I really enjoyed doing.

column2: But if I am tired after each dialysis treatment, will I be able to work at all?&rdquo
column3: The fears for the future made me place high demands on myself. I was demanding more than was possible for me to do. I have to tell you: I lived in a state of constant dissatisfaction because I wasn&rsquo
column4: t able to achieve the goals I&rsquo
column5: d set for myself. It wasn&rsquo
column6: t an easy process, but I started to understand that the simplest way forward would be to set clear and achievable objectives.

column1: First, I tried to understand what my qualities were, as a professional. Then, I accepted that days would come when I would be frustrated. I learned to lower my expectations when I knew, upfront, that it would be harder for me to achieve my goals. From that moment on, everything changed. I decided that the days when I had dialysis would be my days off, and that the days without treatment would be my &ldquo
column3: days, when I would need to work twice as hard to compensate for the days I &ldquo
column5: resting. This made me feel pumped with energy. I went to work with a sense of purpose, approaching my potential customers with a reinvigorated spirit. The result: sales soared. The goals I&rsquo
column7: s success started to come to fruition and everything went much better.

column1: Allowing ourselves to adapt to reality is extremely important, in order for us to live lives in which we are happy and capable of dealing with whatever the day throws at us.
Many of us plan for the future. This is normal and reasonable to do. However, we mustn&rsquo
column2: t forget that our lives are happening now. We should look at plans we have set, with fresh eyes, in order not to fall into the trap of failure. That can lead us, once more, into denial. Staying focused on the present makes each second of each day count and thus we avoid wasting hours (and days) annoyed with ourselves and with those around us. If we stay focused in the present, and remember that life is happening now, we will savour each victory when we achieve a goal that we had set. As a consequence, we&rsquo
column5: m good at what I do&rdquo
column6: gives a sense of wellbeing and of love, even in the simplest actions of our day-to-day life.

column2: Accepting oneself, failing, learning from one&rsquo
column3: s mistakes and always being grateful

column1: Self-acceptance lets us see how we can start afresh. This is what dialysis is: a restart. Life has to be altered to include the thing that allows us to keep on living. Getting rid of the feeling of inferiority that comes from comparing ourselves with people who don&rsquo
column2: t have to go through the same things we do and don&rsquo
column4: have to spend time hooked up to a machine&rdquo
column5: is one step toward treating ourselves better. Doing so can have a massive impact - whether at work, with our family, or in everyday situations like driving a car in busy traffic. Since the time in treatment takes up some of our free time, we have to grasp the time when we are not in treatment and live at 200% intensity!

column1: To live is to make mistakes, but also to improve through them. We should all make the most of our limitations, in order to become better people and to inspire other people through setting an example. This is better than thinking we have the right to complain about everything around us, just because we may feel that we are worth less than others. We aren&rsquo

Being grateful is the best feeling anyone can have. For the simple things, as well as for the things that were hard to get and which required us to fight. By being grateful, we are telling ourselves: I&rsquo
column2: m a winner and this disease won&rsquo
column3: t be the main character in my life.

column1: This is how I feel now: I am a winner. Do you want to be a winner too?

• How we use new technology
A suite of digital platforms and applications designed to improve treatment effectiveness, efficiency and medical outcomes. Transforming renal care, making it accessible and personal
How we use new technology
How we make our work sustainable
<div class=""row""><div class=""block editorialblock col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 display-mode-narrow "">        <div class=""rich-text"">
We aim to provide you with an unprecedented level of care in a personalised and efficient way.

We are moving towards the seamless integration of our physical clinics with new technological approaches, creating a gold-standard and highly scalable kidney care service. And we are committed to bringing this future to our patients and healthcare systems worldwide.
In Sweden and Hungary, our development teams are working on numerous projects to bring new technologies to our care delivery model.

Our continuously evolving digital solutions are vital to our ability to deliver consistent, efficient, high quality care worldwide, while empowering you to contribute to your own care and well-being. Our work is underpinned by the following digital platforms and applications:

Developed by Diaverum for the management of patients and clinics, our renal information management system contains data related to clinical management, medical reporting and clinic processes and administration. It drives clinical workflows and medication management.
Diaverum's PGS advises doctors about optimising medication for you based on your medical data retrieved from the d.CARE renal information management platform.

Our treatment guidance system supports nurses to follow our standardised approach to clinical workflows. This helps to minimise care variability and reduce errors. Our healthcare professionals access the TGS at your chair or bedside via a tablet computer, while the TGS collects and provides information throughout your dialysis, in a paperless environment. The TGS also connects with the Diaverum Enterprise Resource Planning system which manages stock and financial transactions.
d.CONNECT is our fully-automated solution for collecting data from dialysis monitors and weighing scales. This is then used to provide information to the TGS.

column3: education platform which contains information for you as well as for our nurses, physicians and business leaders.

column1: Developed by Diaverum for iOS/Android, this application allows you to communicate directly with our healthcare professionals. You are able to input information about your health and quality of life, and the d.CARE app in turn feeds back to you with information related to your treatment. This is one of several ways that we encourage you to actively engage with us, and with your own care and well-being.
Life enhancing renal care underpinned by clinical and medical standards to ensure consistent quality across all our clinics

Enabling patients to live a fulfilling life
<div class=""row""><div class=""block editorialblock col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 display-mode-narrow "">        <div class=""rich-text"">

For most kidney patients, being on dialysis requires frequent visits to a hospital or clinic so they have access to certain equipment and, in most cases, skilled healthcare staff. As medical care must be guaranteed, being away from home and the accustomed routine can be a challenge.

That's why we created d.HOLIDAY, Diaverum's holiday dialysis programme. A programme which means that renal care patients easily can get access to dialysis care in another city or country - making it possible to visit family or go on holiday.
With over 440 Diaverum clinics around the world, renal care patients have plenty of locations to choose from, ensuring high quality and personalised dialysis care.
Find and book your treatment anywhere

A holistic treatment of our patients is the center of everything we do.
<div class=""row""><div class=""block editorialblock col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 display-mode-narrow "">        <div class=""rich-text"">
Our patients are the focus of everything we do.
We believe that a holistic approach is essential to enhance the life of our patients. Therefore, we offer our patients additional services in our clinics.
We support our patients to make the most of their time, while receiving comprehensive treatment.
There are many different reasons for renal failure. Apart from diabetes, one of the most common one is high blood pressure.
There are many different reasons for renal failure. Apart from high blood pressure, one of the most common once is diabetes.
A healthy diet plays an important role at all stages of chronic kidney disease.

Diaverum provides life enhancing renal care to patients with Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD), enabling them to live fulfilling lives.

column2: s leading providers of renal care. Our core service is haemodialysis, but our expertise stretches from preventive care, to peritoneal dialysis to transplant services.

column1: Diaverum Germany looks back on many years of experience in the field of renal care. At the heart of what we do is our highly standardized care delivery model, which continuously develops. We strive to ensure excellent medical outcomes that exceed the requirements of national health systems. At 16 locations, around 500 employees provide true care to empower our patients to live a fulfilling life. The closely cooperating locations are combined in the nine medical centers of Kleve, Erkelenz, Remscheid, Hamburg, Stralsund, Potsdam, Prignitz and Neubrandenburg.
This is our journey. A timeline of innovation, passion for care excellence we deliver to our patients.
Life enhancing renal care underpinned by clinical and medical standards to ensure consistent quality across all our clinics

How we make our work sustainable
<div class=""row""><div class=""block editorialblock col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 display-mode-narrow "">        <div class=""rich-text"">
Your medical outcomes and safety are of paramount importance, and we have developed a model of care which prioritises these.
All our work is carried out to rigorous standards and evolves in parallel with new advances in renal care and technology, much of which we develop &ldquo
The Diaverum approach to your care has five key strands:
• Clinical standards: policies and procedures that ensure high quality of care and safety
• Medical standards: comprehensive approaches to treatment that optimise medical outcomes through the most efficient care delivery
• Performance measurement: continuous monitoring of medical outcomes
• Patient and staff education: in both virtual and physical settings
• Scientific research: based on what matters most to you

And this approach is not static: we continuously improve our policies and procedures through learning from you, and from our staff, in surveys, regular internal audits and in response to national regulatory demands. Our evidence-based clinical practices are reinforced by a range of approaches to education and training alongside our multi-audience d.ACADEMY platform.
Transparency underpins our work, and our Clinical Performance Measurement (CPM) system measures and compares medical performance within and between our clinics globally.
You can find out more in our
column3: section about our how our care for you is underpinned by constantly evolving technology including proprietary software such as the Renal Information Management System (d.CARE), the Treatment Guidance System (TGS), Pharma Guidance System (PGS) and our virtual education platform, d.ACADEMY.

column1: These digital tools enable us to standardise your care and thus enhance and improve your safety and medical outcomes while allowing us to better manage our workflow.
We are committed to enhancing your Diaverum experience

Through the MyDiaverumExperience portal you can submit feedback regarding any experience you’ve had with Diaverum, that you would like to bring to our attention. You may do so in your local language and anonymously, if you wish.
Submit your feedback via MyDiaverumExperience
A suite of digital platforms and applications designed to improve treatment effectiveness, efficiency and medical outcomes. Transforming renal care, making it accessible and personal

Our focus is haemodialysis, but our portfolio of treatments ranges from preventive care to transplantation services.
<div class=""row""><div class=""block editorialblock col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 display-mode-narrow "">        <div class=""rich-text"">
When severe loss of kidney function occurs, it must be replaced through transplant or dialysis. Dialysis is most common, either in the form of haemodialysis (HD) or as peritoneal dialysis (PD).
Many patients on dialysis can have a reasonably normal life and can travel, exercise, and work.

column2: s focus is haemodialysis, but we offer a portfolio of treatments ranging from preventive care, peritoneal dialysis and home care to coordination of patients&rsquo

column1: Haemodialysis removes toxic substances that have accumulated in your blood as a result of kidney failure
Peritoneal dialysis is a kidney replacement therapy that takes place inside your body without any blood manipulation
Kidney transplantation is a surgical option of treatment when the kidneys fail

<div class=""row""><div class=""block editorialblock col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 display-mode-narrow "">        <div class=""rich-text"">

column2: Swedish-born, multinational healthcare organisation that provides life-enhancing renal care to patients with Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD), empowering them to live fulfilling lives.&nbsp
column3: As the largest independent renal service provider in Europe, we&nbsp
column4: care for around 38,000 patients across 440 clinics in 23 countries globally.

column5: a portfolio of treatments ranging from preventive care, haemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis and home care, to coordination of patients&rsquo

column1: CKD is a global and escalating challenge today affecting about 10% of the world&rsquo
column3: s primarily caused by lifestyle diseases such as diabetes, and its prevalence is increasing, particularly in developing countries and among low income individuals. We ensure that our clinics are a safe and familiar space where all our patients are made to feel welcome.

column1: Our vision is to transform the industry through patient-centric digital innovations,

At the centre of what we do is our standardised, proprietary care delivery model, enabled by a continuously evolving digital infrastructure. We strive to ensure superior medical outcomes exceeding those demanded by national healthcare systems and we support patients by improving personalised care, ease of use and new services through technology.
Diaverum employs approximately 13,000 people and operates 440 clinics in 23 countries globally. Diaverum has its head office in Malmö

We put high emphasis on scientific research
How we make our work sustainable
<div class=""row""><div class=""block editorialblock col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 display-mode-narrow "">        <div class=""rich-text"">
Scientific researh is very important to us. Scientific projects of our employees are highly encouraged and supported by Diaverum.
Our research serves to gain general medical knowledge and is intended to be of particular benefit to Diaverum patients. We use modern research methods to identify kidney diseases at an early stage.

With effective therapy, the progressive decline in kidney function and cardiovascular diseases such as heart attacks or strokes, which are often associated with kidney diseases, can be avoided or delayed.
We offer our patients the opportunity to participate in ongoing clinical studies with innovative drugs or therapeutic methods.
• Scientifically evaluated quality assurance for kidney failure with or without dialysis
• New methods of kidney values and laboratory tests
For further questions about our research, please contact Prof. Dr. Rainer Woitas.
<a aria-label=""How we make our work sustainable"" href=""/de/en/diaverum-germany/how-we-make-our-work-sustainable/"">
How we make our work sustainable
We want to improve access to high-quality renal care and we deliver it with competence, passion and inspiration.
A suite of digital platforms and applications designed to improve treatment effectiveness, efficiency and medical outcomes. Transforming renal care, making it accessible and personal
Life enhancing renal care underpinned by clinical and medical standards to ensure consistent quality across all our clinics

Diaverum Germany acquires a new dialysis clinic in Prignitz-Perleberg.

Diaverum, a leading global provider for renal care services, is acquiring a new dialysis clinic in the district of Prignitz-Perleberg in Brandenburg bringing its portfolio to 9 medical treatment centers in Germany.

On 1 October, Diaverum Germany is taking over the Prignitz-Perleberg dialysis centre. Until now, the clinic has been run by the owners Prof. Willi Grunewald and Dr. Ilona Lange, who, together with their team of more than 20 employees, look after around 100 dialysis patients on site. For 23 years now, the Perleberg site has been supplying the population of the district with a wide range of renal care services, and this should remain the case in the future.

column2: Our goal is to ensure long-term health care in the region,"" emphasises former owner Prof. Grunewald, adding that Diaverum is the perfect partner for this.

column1: For patients, the full range of services will be available and all employees will also be transferred as part of the change in operation.

""Diaverum is recognised worldwide for its high standards of care and very good medical outcomes. We look forward to continuing this success story under the competent leadership of Professor Grunewald and Doctor Lange in Perleberg,"" explains Pascal Neujean, Managing Director of Diaverum Germany.

Our focus is our people. Our teams consist of professional and competent people who care and who want to make a difference.
<div class=""row""><div class=""block editorialblock col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 display-mode-narrow "">        <div class=""rich-text"">

Our focus on providing world-class renal care for every one of our patients in each of our clinics is made possible by the professionalism and competence of our staff. People who care, and who want to make a difference.

Our networks provide the opportunity for personal growth and development on an international level. As described below, we are a diverse team of people from different backgrounds and professions. As well as seeking the best talent from within healthcare,
column2: we are eager to learn from other sectors and embrace people who want to make a step into our world.

column1:
Our nurses make up the majority of our staff. They are the ones who create a direct and lasting link with our patients and improve their quality of life every day. Our nurses are our care and treatment experts and participate in several company-wide programs for personal development and exchanging ideas.

When filling our care team, we follow the current dialysis standard of the German Society of Nephrology. It defines the qualification requirements for nursing staff in dialysis.
As such, we employ qualified nurses, healthcare professionals, and medical specialists. We also employ pediatric nurses and geriatric nurses for dialysis.

Prior knowledge of dialysis is of course an advantage, but it is not a precondition for employment. We also hope to see fluent German language skills, an open and trusting nature, team spirit, and empathy for the interests of our patients and their relatives.

Doctors are our experts in medical excellence. They ensure that we follow the highest standards of renal care, while also overseeing our patient-centric research and scientific programs. At Diaverum, our training program gives doctors access to state-of-the-art knowledge, a place where they can share their experience and learn from each other. Together, they make sure that we are the best in our field and that we pass on our knowledge to the rest of the world.

As we expand our medical teams across all our clinics, we are looking for internal medicine physicians specializing in nephrology. However, we would also be happy to take on young colleagues still completing further nephrologist training. We place great importance on open and collegial cooperation, professional expertise, empathy for our patients and their individual needs, and a focus on goals.

If you have any questions about working as a doctor at Diaverum Deutschland, our Medical Director Prof. Dr. Rainer Woitas is happy to hear from you.

Our nurses and doctors are supported by other staff members in patient care. These people ensure that we are able to operate our clinics at the highest possible standards, and they help coordinate the many treatment services we offer our patients.

Service staff support our work by accompanying dialysis patients to their places, by providing food at the individual dialysis stations, by preparing the trolleys with treatment materials, or by preparing and cleaning/organizing the treatment rooms.
For this staff, we like to see training as a nursing assistant or experience in the health sector, but this is not a prerequisite. However, you should bring an open and friendly nature and demonstrate reliability.

Our technicians keep the dialysis machines in good working order and make sure they are provisioned properly. They service, repair, and supply around 90 dialysis machines in our Hamburg clinic on Alte Teichweg, for example. Applicants must have completed technical training, preferably with experience in medical devices and a reliable and structured work style.

As the face of the clinic, our medical specialists are usually seen at the outpatient clinics. They greet our patients and their relatives, take them in for treatment, take blood samples or perform other laboratory tests, or provide assistance with billing.
Applicants must have completed medical specialist training, preferably with professional experience. However, you are also welcome to join us as soon as you have completed your training. Applicants should be fluent in German, have a friendly and open nature, and enjoy dealing with people. We like to give our patients an open ear and an understanding of their individual concerns.

You can learn more about open positions and vacancies here.
Maria - 33 years at our Kleve clinic
Through empowerment, education and training we grow together.
Diaverum offers healthcare professionals diverse opportunities for careers in many countries.
This is our manifesto. It’s what guides everything we do.

Diaverum offers healthcare professionals diverse opportunities for careers in many countries.
<div class=""row""><div class=""block editorialblock col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 display-mode-narrow "">        <div class=""rich-text"">
Diaverum recognises that there is a shortage of clinical staff in some countries, and therefore offers healthcare professionals diverse opportunities to re-locate their career.

The lack of qualified nurses and doctors on the German labour market is also affecting Diaverum. We are looking forward to the support of colleagues from abroad in order to maintain the highest standards of patient care.
We have already proven the benefits of an international workforce at several of our clinics. New colleagues bring new perspectives and ideas as well as their experience working in their home countries.

To start working at one of our centres in Germany, interested parties must demonstrate the equivalence of qualifications obtained abroad (training or degree). This will be checked by the respective German authority. Sufficient German language skills are also required. Applicants must have at least a B2 level, according to the European Framework of Reference for Languages.
A certificate of health and personal suitability must also be provided.

More detailed information can be found on the &ldquo
column3: page of the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research. Here you can view the recognition requirements for your foreign professional qualification as well as which documents you must submit in particular.

Through empowerment, education and training we grow together.
<div class=""row""><div class=""block editorialblock col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 display-mode-narrow "">        <div class=""rich-text"">
Delivering excellent care requires us to have educated and empowered people at the heart of our business, and we seek to nurture them throughout their careers.

We are a constantly growing organisation and we want to encourage new potential and see our employees grow with us. We achieve this through empowerment, education, training and diverse career opportunities.

Every year, many of our centres offer young people the opportunity to start training as medical assistants. This gives them the opportunity to gradually learn how things work everyday at the centre, to take on responsibility, and to work independently. Trainees can also learn about dialysis if they are interested and eligible.
The prerequisites for entry here are: a successfully completed school leaving certificate, a passion and interest in patient care and support, an organized and reliable work style, and fluent German language skills.

You can find more information on training as a medical assistant

""If you rest, you rust"". That is how the old saying we have heard many times goes. However, as with all the sayings, there is some truth to it. After all, those who do not develop stay where they are.
This is how we see it at Diaverum Deutschland. Only by training and educating our staff can we continue to ensure the highest level of care for our dialysis patients.
We make this possible with our internal training tools such as d.ACADEMY. Here we encourage our employees to develop and expand on their professional and personal skills. Our nurses, doctors, managers, and patients have access to a variety of e-learning programmes. The innovative d.ACADEMY, for instance, is a genuine knowledge exchange, from experts for experts, and based on the results of groundbreaking scientific research. d.ACADEMY also includes a digital library for personal development which has information on topics like soft skills or project management training.

We also induct new employees through our d.ACADEMY. In addition to accompanying our experienced mentors and practical instructors trained in everyday dialysis work, new employees receive professionally prepared training documents for an introduction to dialysis. Here we explain possible complications of dialysis, the causes of these complications, and how to prevent and treat them, for example. We also provide detailed information on the different types of vascular access and the necessary care.

column2: s e-learning offerings, our employees have the opportunity to learn from additional internal and external medical training programmes. These are organised in the clinics. If an employee needs specific knowledge, in-house experts or external training staff are ready to help.

column1: Our nurses also have the opportunity to participate in specialised training on nephrology. After at least two years of professional experience, including at least six months of continuous experience in nephrology, trained nursing staff can then reinforce and expand on their specialised knowledge in various practical and theoretical phases. They also have the chance to deepen their knowledge of specialist fields.
Furthermore, we are pleased when nurses are willing to participate in further training courses such as practical guidance, nutritional advice, or quality management.

There are no limits on employee development here. We see this with our trainees, for example, who take on more and more responsibility over time after completing their own training, going all the way to nursing management.
Diaverum offers healthcare professionals diverse opportunities for careers in many countries.
Our focus is our people. Our teams consist of professional and competent people who care and who want to make a difference.
Our culture is all about how we empower our patients to live a fulfilling life. We combine professional skills in patient care with a caring, human touch.

name"":""Jennifer - A story full of possibilities"",
• Jennifer - A story full of possibilities
From dialysis nurse to head nurse
Maria - 33 years at our Kleve clinic
Jennifer - A story full of possibilities
Meet Shirley, a UK nurse at Diaverum
My name is Jennifer Hempel and I started my 3-year professional training as a physician assistant at the MVZ Diaverum Erkelenz in August 2009.
column2: After completing my apprenticeship, I joined the clinic as a dialysis nurse. I had never thought that I would eventually take on the position as head nurse, as there were enough colleagues with more experience at the clinic. Nevertheless, I took over the position in September 2020. My work includes many administrative and organisational tasks, such as drafting the rostering arrangements, the general organisation in the clinic, and ensuring that everything runs according to policies. Of course, I continue to care for our patients during dialysis, which I am incredibly happy about. I particularly enjoy working with patients. As you see patients usually 3 times a week, you end up having a very good relationship with many of them. In addition to caring for patients, I particularly like about my work that every day is different and you never really know what will happen next and how stressful the day might be. My work is incredibly varied and not too monotonous.

column1: During the time I've worked at Diaverum, I have experienced a lot and, above all, I've seen many colleagues come and go. And I still remember very well that at that time I was not convinced that I would be staying in dialysis. But what can I say? I don't regret a second of the time that I have stayed here. When things get tough you think about throwing the towel in, but quite honestly, I always asked myself what would await me somewhere else? And there was no answer to that.

I feel at home here and I have an absolutely great team that can always be relied on. Because of the team and our great clinic manager, I enjoy going to work each day. We have a great time together and are like a small family that is there for each other, no matter how bad things get. Team spirit is simply right here. And that's why I'm also happy to be a part of Diaverum and am very grateful for the trust placed in me here and for the opportunity to grow and invest in myself. I don't take that for granted.

name"":""Maria - 33 years at our Kleve clinic"",
• Maria - 33 years at our Kleve clinic
From everday life in dialysis and the fun of it
Maria - 33 years at our Kleve clinic
Jennifer - A story full of possibilities
Meet Shirley, a UK nurse at Diaverum

I am Maria Venhoff and long ago, after completing my training, I worked in the Internal Medicine Department at St. Josef Hospital in Moers.
After the birth of my second child, I cut my work schedule down to working every second weekend and every second holiday. At that time, Dr. Paul was looking for a nurse for the evening shift at his outpatient dialysis facility in Kleve. I introduced myself and was hired immediately. It was a stressful time at the beginning, since I did not have any experience in dialysis. Some nights, I dreamed of beeping machines. I committed myself to this new task, and I have never lost the fun of it. This is also demonstrated by my long affiliation with Dialyse Kleve, where I have been for 33 years. And even when the centre became Diaverum in 2010, the joy remained.
My work area includes tasks such as patient care, organization, ordering, invoice verification, and documentation. I like the variety of activities, the high degree of personal responsibility, the technical requirements, and even the documentation work. For several years now, I have handled nursing management at the centre, which entails a lot of personnel responsibility. And working in a good team, which always supported me to the best of their abilities, has kept me motivated over the years and kept me coming to work every day!

<div class=""row""><div class=""block shareblock col-lg-12 col-md-12 col-sm-12 col-xs-12  "">
The two 14 year old pupils Luca and Nico used Boys' Day on 27 April 2023 to take a look at everyday working life at the MVZ Stralsund.
The event was led by the Head Nurse Grit Kolbe, together with Cassandra Hä
column2: uer, 3rd year trainee, and Wolfgang Rudolf, specialist nurse for nephrology. The two got to know the team, the location in Jungfernstieg and the various training opportunities offered by Diaverum in Stralsund.

column1: Wolfgang Rudolf vividly explained the basic principle of dialysis and water supply to the two pupils. He had brought along some practical examples and loosened up the conversation with quiz questions.

A peritoneal dialysis patient could be won for a report from the patient's point of view. She reported on her many years of experience with peritoneal dialysis and on her care and support at Diaverum.
Finally, the young people learned from Cassandra Hä
column2: uer how she came to the MFA training
column3: she also told about her three-year training at Diaverum.

column1: All in all, it was a successful day and we hope that we were able to give the two teens a small but comprehensive insight into everyday life at a dialysis centre. In any case, we are already looking forward to the next Boys' Day!

Diaverum and Nipro seal long-term and mutually value-adding partnership
<div class=""row""><div class=""block shareblock col-lg-12 col-md-12 col-sm-12 col-xs-12  "">
On 24 April, a delegation from Diaverum led by the company&rsquo
column2: s CEO, Mr. Dimitris Moulavasilis, met with Nipro&rsquo
column3: s President, Mr. Yoshihiko Sano, at the new Nipro Corporation Japan headquarters in Osaka, Japan, to mark the signing and official commencement of a prolonged partnership between the parties.

column1: Diaverum and Nipro are committed to further strengthening ties and exploring long-term opportunities for continued and diversified collaboration in many areas, reinforcing Nipro&rsquo
column2: s role as a strategic partner of Diaverum. The concept of &ldquo
column4: resonates with both companies, who share the ultimate goal of delivering the best possible patient outcomes by providing efficient, holistic, and adequate treatment solutions.

column2: We value Nipro as a strategic partner for its comprehensive portfolio, good logistics, and extensive field presence globally. This long-term and wider scope partnership with Nipro will strengthen our ability to manage inflationary pressures and enjoy efficiencies in strategic areas, ultimately benefiting patients and healthcare systems worldwide&rdquo

We have been working with Diaverum since 2008, supporting the healthcare organisation with high-value products and reliable customer service. As well as an extension of the partnership, the number and types of products that would be supplied have also expanded.&rdquo

column1: Nipro Medical Europe is part of Nipro Corporation Japan, a leading global healthcare company established in 1954. With over 35,000 employees worldwide, Nipro serves the Medical Device, Pharmaceutical, and Pharmaceutical Packaging industries.

Am 24. April traf eine Delegation von Diaverum unter der Leitung des CEO Dimitris Moulavasilis mit dem Prä
column2: sidenten von Nipro, Yoshihiko Sano, in der neuen Zentrale der Nipro Corporation Japan in Osaka, Japan, zusammen, um die Unterzeichnung und den offiziellen Beginn einer langfristigen Partnerschaft zwischen den Parteien zu feiern.

column1: Diaverum und Nipro sind entschlossen, ihre Beziehungen weiter zu vertiefen und langfristige Mö
column3: r eine fortgesetzte und breit gef&auml
column4: cherte Zusammenarbeit in vielen Bereichen zu sondieren, was die Rolle von Nipro als strategischer Partner von Diaverum st&auml
column5: rkt. Das Konzept der ""Value-Based-Care"" findet bei beiden Unternehmen Anklang, die das ultimative Ziel teilen, durch effiziente, ganzheitliche und ad&auml

column1: Dimitris Moulavasilis, CEO von Diaverum, sagte: ""Wir schä
column2: tzen Nipro als strategischen Partner aufgrund seines umfassenden Portfolios, seiner guten Logistik und seiner umfassenden weltweiten Pr&auml
column3: senz vor Ort. Diese langfristige und weitreichendere Partnerschaft mit Nipro wird unsere F&auml
column5: ltigung des Inflationsdrucks und zur Erzielung von Effizienzgewinnen in strategischen Bereichen st&auml
column6: rken, was letztendlich den Patienten und den Gesundheitssystemen weltweit zugute kommt"".

column2: sident von Nipro, sagte: ""Wir arbeiten seit 2008 mit Diaverum zusammen und unterst&uuml
column3: tzen die Gesundheitsorganisation mit hochwertigen Produkten und einem zuverl&auml
column4: ssigen Kundenservice. Neben der Ausweitung der Partnerschaft haben sich auch die Anzahl und die Art der zu liefernden Produkte erweitert.""

column2: r eine Nierentransplantation geeignet ist, kann es sein, dass Sie dadurch ein normaleres Leben f&uuml

column3: glicherweise haben Sie weitere Erkrankungen, die eine Transplantation zu kompliziert oder riskant machen. Sie m&uuml
column4: ssen auch zur Maximierung des langfristigen Transplantationserfolgs eine Niere erhalten, die den verschiedenen Merkmalen Ihres eigenen K&ouml
column7: hrt eine Transplantation von einem lebenden Spender, der mit Ihnen verwandt ist, zu den besten Ergebnissen.

column1: Wie bei den meisten medizinischen Verfahren sind mit einer Transplantation Risiken verbunden, und es mü
column2: ssen zur Feststellung der Eignung viele Untersuchungen durchgef&uuml
column3: hrt werden. Dabei werden sowohl die Eigenschaften Ihres Immunsystems als auch Ihre allgemeine k&ouml

column1: Wenn eine Transplantation eine gute Option fü
column2: r Sie ist, werden Ihnen Ihr medizinisches Team und andere Spezialisten dabei helfen, alle Einzelheiten zu verstehen. Vielleicht empfinden Sie es auch als hilfreich, mit jemandem zu sprechen, der bereits eine Transplantation erhalten hat
column3: Ihr medizinisches Team kann das auf Wunsch einrichten.

column5: hrung, Medikation und allgemeiner Lebensweise einhalten. Sie tragen auch ein h&ouml

column2: nnen von verstorbenen Menschen, von verwandten oder nicht verwandten Lebendspendern wie Partnern oder Freunden stammen. In einigen L&auml
column4: nnen sie auch von unbekannten Spendern kommen, die dieses altruistische Geschenk machen wollen.

column1: Es gibt nicht genug Organe zur Transplantation, und Sie mü
column3: glicherweise Monate oder sogar Jahre warten, bevor Sie eine Transplantationsniere erhalten. Ihr medizinisches Team gibt Ihnen alle notwendigen Informationen &uuml
column4: ber die Regelungen und Wartelisten an Ihrem Wohnort.
